repnme.cdata!:
Central African Republic - Fiscal
            Consolidation Credit Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The ratings for the Fiscal Consolidated
            Credit for Central Africa were as follows: the outcome was
            unsatisfactory, the sustainability was unlikely, the
            institutional development impact was negligible, and the
            Bank and borrower performance were both unsatisfactory. The
            credit had the potential to be an effective instrument in an
            emergency, post-conflict situation, for improving the
            provision of government services, stimulating private sector
            development, and generally enhancing the prospects for
            national reconciliation. When faced with a strong
            political/reputational pressure to move in a difficult and
            poor security environment, the Bank should also consider the
            effectiveness and sustainability of its budgetary
            assistance, both factors bearing higher reputational risks
            in the medium to long term. The right approach is to state
            clearly that the Bank has endorsed the Low-Income Countries
            Under Stress (LICUS) principles, and it is committed to stay
            engaged even in most difficult circumstances. However, for
            budgetary support, four factors should be taken into
            account: (i) a sound macroeconomic framework should be in
            place; (ii) there should be some prior investment in
            knowledge so as to design a relevant and realistic reform
            program; (iii) Bank support should be part of a broader
            international assistance package, with most donors endorsing
            a common platform; (iv) a candid assessment of the internal
            process in place to address unrest, including the quality of
            the national dialogue and reconciliation efforts, should be
            undertaken. For a country like Central African Republic
            (CAR) emerging from a devastating conflict, with disruptions
            in administrative capacity and a distressed economy, the
            capacity to raise domestic revenue is most likely limited in
            the short-term, and therefore balance of payments support is
            needed. Preparation of relevant and good quality Economic
            and Sector Work (ESW) and policy notes is a critical
            prerequisite for a meaningful policy dialogue with the
            government and preparation of loans/credits. Privatization
            of public enterprises and utilities involves complicated
            processes and requires careful sequencing. For LICUS-type
            countries such CAR, the focus of the Bank assistance should
            be on building capacity in the government to implement
            reforms and improve delivery of services.

repnme.cdata!:
Central African Republic - Fiscal
            Consolidation Credit Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The Fiscal Consolidation Credit Project
            will consist of measures to consolidate public finance,
            supporting the Government's program, and accelerate
            privatization of key public enterprises, within the context
            of the Central African Republic post-conflict. The project
            will help the Government achieve its basic functions -
            particularly regularize payment of salaries to civil
            servants and the military - while enhancing the prospects
            for peace in a still fragile post-conflict environment.
            Furthermore, the external debt will be serviced, improving
            external credibility, thus inducing external assistance to
            foster private investments, and achieve the required
            development growth. However, political instability risks a
            still fragile peace, which could be riskier without the
            budget support provided by this operation, and the Fund for
            Enhanced Structural Adjustment Facility (ESAF). A further
            risk is the resistance to change, and opposition from vested
            interests - including revenue agencies - although, actions
            taken recently by the Government, namely lowering of cotton
            prices, have provided credible signals of sustained support
            from the International Development Agency (IDA), hence,
            reducing the risk of backtracking. Donor coordination for
            additional assistance will be required to
            demobilize/restructure the military, and develop human
            resources, and physical infrastructure.
